list_definition.definition: a white rock; a type of limestone

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The soil is made of chalk and clay.

list_definition.definition: (a piece of) a chalk-like substance used for writing (especially on blackboards)

list_ex_of_english: Hoch was released at the end of his jail term, chalking up another 15 wives before his ultimate arrest in 1905.
In the election in the south in 1978, chalked on the pavement was the figure 78.
The seconds solved the difficulty by chalking out a portion of the fat man's body to equal that of his opponent.
There are the men chalking up the prices on the wall.
The £2,000 million deficit that we chalked up in 1974 is running at a rate of £2,400 million in the first quarter of 1975.
If one can demonstrate that, or make it appear probable in one line of research rather than another, a score is chalked up for that line.
On the day of my visit the menu was chalked up on a blackboard.
The way the chalk image was made, and made to be seen, shatters that neutrality.
